title: Generating Synchronicity: Vitality and Relatedness in Southwest China
abstractText:
This project explores the hypothesis that religio-medical practices have developed sophisticated linguistic devices and bodily techniques for endorsing the therepeutic principle of "generating synchronicity" between practitioner and patient.

Synchronicity arises when practitioner and patient focus on a single event, which breaks down habitual boundaries between them and generates space for negotiating uncertainty and interpersonal relations. This is thought to create a sense of relatedness between them, which, in turn, is considered to enhance vitality.

In order to explore how people generate synchronicity through (1) the use of vague and/or polysemous concepts during the therepeutic encounter and (2) tactility, the researchers will carry out language-competent ethnographic field research in Southwest China. The field results will be complemented with a seminar series and a conference on the broader theme of "Blood, Vitality and Relatedness in Eastern Medicines and Religions".
